text.__SUMMARY__: Eucalyptus saxatilis, commonly known as the Suggan Buggan mallee or Mount Wheeler mallee, is a mallee or small tree, native to southeastern Australia.
text.Description: The species may grow up to 8 metres in height and has smooth bark, which is grey-green and sheds in short ribbons. The juvenile leaves are opposite and glaucous. The adult leaves are bluish grey and falcate to laceolate. These  are 10 to 15 cm long and 1 to 2 cm wide.
text.Taxonomy: The species was first formally described  by J.B. Kirkpatrick and M.I.H. Brooker in Australian Forest Research in 1977 from material collected at Little River Gorge in the Snowy River National Park.
text.Distribution and habitat: The species occurs in eastern Victoria and south-eastern New South Wales in Australia.
text.Distribution and habitat-Conservation: Eucalyptus saxatilis was one of eleven species selected for the Save a Species Walk campaign in April 2016; scientists walked 300 km to raise money for collection of seeds to be prepared and stored at the Australian PlantBank at the Australian Botanic Garden, Mount Annan.
